"For all that die the priest shall pray,

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Hear me, my good men of the mountains; hearken! A long story I shall not tell you, for I am not fond of talking; and because I hate lying I will tell you no story at all.—This same Lazarra is a foreign scoundrel, a stranger to our nation, and no Swiss. He has no business here: What does he come for? I'll tell you what—for plunder—to drive you out of your cabins, as he has drove the worthy Lord of Thurn out of his castle—Will you suffer it?

sp.speaker: MOUNTAINEER.
sp.p: No, no, we will not—we'll revenge Lord Albert.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: I knew you wou'd; I knew you were true Swiss, and wou'd not let those villainous interlopers tread in your lovely snows, and track your pleasant mountains, where nothing grows but icicles and liberty.—Lord love you, you remember poor old Wolf; you have the steam of the castle kitchen still in your nostrils, and know I was not the Wolf at the door to keep you out, but to invite you in—You bear all this in mind; I know you do.

sp.speaker: MOUNTAINEER.
sp.p: We do, my master, therefore say no more, but march!

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Oh yes; I'll march—Lazarra pays the piper, so strike up! We hav'nt got the true step, but no matter: We'll trot, and our enemies shall gallop.

div2.stage: (PHILIP is seen ascending from the Subterranean. He assists Lord ALBERT, and they come forward.)

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord, where are you? reach your hand; I've found the passage; the fresh air salutes us, and the bright moon subscribes her friendly beam.—Welcome to liberty.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: My brave deliverer, come to my heart.

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p:
It is the proudest aim of my ambition to be near your heart. But you are faint, the subterranean damps hang on you still. Within this
cave you'll find repose and shelter; enter it, my Lord. I will ascend the heighths, kindle a fire, and bring the mountaineers to your assistance.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Thanks, gallant youth! a faintness steals upon me; I must confess to you I need repose.—Ah, Philip, to be torn from those we love dearer than life, and in the hour of danger, by strong necessity driven to desert them, judge how it wrings my heart!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: I do—I judge, I feel it by my own.—No more, but enter. (ALBERT enters the Hermit's cave.) Oh Eloisa; 'tis thy cause no less than Albert's, that gives wings to my impatience.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Here is my cell. We'll take a short repose, and then resume our flight.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: And wilt thou suffer all this for me? Wilt thou for me exhaust the small remains of strength that age has left thee; thou pure benevolence, thou more than parent to poor deserted Eloisa?

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: I'll not permit thee to despond, my child. There is a Providence, that bear me up above my body's strength in thy protection. I feel as if I were again a father, and my lost daughter liv'd again in thee: fear nothing then: within this peaceful cell thou wilt find viands of your own bestowing.—Enter!—What ails thee?— There is nothing there; no dying man to fright thee.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Ah, he's there! the very man. I see him there— Lord Albert, stretcht on the floor, and dying, as it seems.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Merciful Heaven defend us! who is this?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Be not thus cast in wonder. I am Albert, not dying, as she thinks, but sav'd from death, if you betray me not.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: If we betray you! we are not those that wou'd betray the wretch that fled from justice to invoke protection; how then shou'd we betray the good Lord Albert, the patron of the needy and opprest, the orphan's father and the widow's friend? Blest be the hand that rescued thee from death! Say who it was, that I may pray for him.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Philip of Belmont.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Oh approving Heaven, crown him, reward him for the glorious deed. My Philip has preserv'd you; I acquit him. I was in like extremity with you at the same hour; I call'd him to my rescue in vain; his virtue triumph'd o'er his love. He turn'd from me and sav'd his benefactor. I praise him, I applaud him for the choice: you had a husband's and a father's claim; for you the hearts of thousands wou'd have bled; for me none other than his own.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Ah, father, if you knew the Lord of Thurn.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: I hope he has been taught to know himself in his adversity.—I knew his father.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: I'm sorry for it, if you knew him rightly; for then you know what cause I have to blush, when I am falsely stil'd the Lord of Thurn.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: That to confess bespeaks a candid mind; for that I honour you; but Thurn is lost. What then remains?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Before to-morrow's dawn either to see Lazarra at my feet, or see the light no more: if on the walls my banner flies, it flies not for myself, but for the daughter of that rightful Lord, who in his banishment was basely murder'd.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Alas, that daughter never will be found, nor was that father murder'd; he yet lives, and I am he. Yes, Albert, I, I am that wretched father; degraded, exil'd, and at once bereft of wife, son, daughter; outcast of the world; no home, no country, not one friend on earth, save this sweet innocent, the feeble staff of an old beggar tottering to his grave.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Oh heavenly justice, how did I escape, whilst you was begging at that castle's gate, which I, unconscious of your right, usurp'd?

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: That I am Theodore, the banisht Lord of Thurn and its domain, I had in proof to shew one relick, which the robbers miss'd, my crest (a crowned lion) cut in ruby; but this last pledge I left in Guntram's hands for purposes, which this dear child can witness.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: There needs no witness to the truth you utter; and here, in presence of high Heaven, I swear to pay you homage, and restore your right.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: No, no, your virtues have aton'd to justice; you, Albert, have the blessings of the poor: Had I possession, what cou'd I have more? I have no daughter; the inhuman villains, that robb'd and left me dying, kill'd my child. Within that cell I have preserv'd one relick, one mournful relick. —You shall see my store.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: I saw no relick. What does he allude to?

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Alas! I know not. My heart melts with pity.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: This mourful story is not new to you.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: My Lord, I've often ask'd, but never heard it: he always put me by when I made suit to share his sorrows—but behold he comes.

div2.stage: HERMIT returns with a bloody mantle.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p:
This, this is all that's left me of my daughter;
this garment purpled as you see with blood.— Here stream'd that life-blood than my own more dear; and tho' my tears have almost blanch'd the spots, they cannot wash away the deep remembrance of my afflicting loss.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Oh agonizing sight!

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Unhappy father, what can I do for thee?

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Nothing for me: childless and old, forgetting this vain world, and by the world forgotten, for myself I only ask a grave—but for this innocent whom I have snatcht from misery, and who clings, as if by nature's charter, to my heart—for her I make appeal to your protection, and as in honour you shall deal with her, so may Heaven deal forgiveness to your father.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: She is my care henceforth; and would to Heaven, when thus I take her hand in pledge of faith, 'twas in my power to say—Behold your daughter.

sp.speaker: DARBONY.
sp.p: That is the damsel; seize and take her hence.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Heaven! shew thy mercy!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Villains! loose your hold!

sp.speaker: DARBONY.
sp.p:
Shall I not take my own? She is my wife: Away with her!—Lord Albert, stand aside; I've
done you more than wrong enough already: besides, you are unarm'd.

div2.stage: (She is forced off by DARBONY's soldiers.)

sp.speaker: ELOISA
sp.p: Philip! Philip!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Stop! stop! A rescue!

sp.speaker: DARBONY.
sp.p: Stop thy clamorous tongue, grey-headed hypocrite. March on, my hearts!

sp.speaker: ELOISA
sp.p: Philip! Philip!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: 'Tis Eloisa's voice! Friends! brethren! follow.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Follow! the vengeance! I have burst my heart with following; and that madcap, Philip, leads them off at score. Holloa! who's that? My noble master living! Here! here's a sword; carve for yourself, and spare not: first come, first serv'd; no ceremony at this sport.

div2.stage: (ALBERT and WOLF follow to the fight.)

sp.speaker: HERMIT
sp.p: There, there they go! and now the wood conceals them: now they come out; see! see! they're close upon them! they meet! they fight! Philip has conquer'd! Hark! our people shout: the coward miscreants throw away their arms, and beg for mercy. Hah! she lives! she lives!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: Joy! triumph! victory! Eloisa's sav'd!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: My child! my child! Oh, welcome to my sight! My old heart bounds with transport to behold thee.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Bring in your prisoner; we have got their leader.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Let me come to him; I've had a taste of his sword, now he shall have a belly full of mine.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Hold! hold! 'tis Darbony; he spar'd my life: I'll not take his.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: But I will for you; that will do as well.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Forbear! thou art too bloody.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: You see I am: he has drawn my blood; why should not I open a vein for him?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Stand off, and quit him! What is your pretence for seizing this young woman?

sp.speaker: DARBONY.
sp.p: If I had seiz'd her, and secur'd my prize, I should have had a title, Lord of Thurn, superior to your own.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: What do you mean? Is she not Guntram's daughter?

sp.speaker: DARBONY.
sp.p: I am your prisoner; you have sav'd my life: therefore I tell you fairly, not one drop of Guntram's blood runs in those noble veins: I would not treat with him till he confess'd it. I marry Guntram's daughter!—no! He stole her, like a thief: she is the daughter of Theodore, the ancient Lord of Thurn; and had I married her—

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Break off! the father, the father stands before you!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Oh! my daughter!

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Philip, support me! bear me to his feet, that I may kneel.—Oh! tell me, tell me truly, if it was nature's instinct that inspir'd me to love thee, honour thee, and call thee father?

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! how wonderful art thou in mercy! I'm lost: the blessing is too vast for me; my weak frame totters: lead me to my cell.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: How's this, old friend? A tear on that rough cheek?

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Yes, a rough tear; not one of your soft drops, that whimpering pity sheds: I never weep, except for joy that honest men are happy. Come, signor Darbony, enter the cell: you are not overburden'd with humanity; a few more lessons of this sort won't hurt you.

div2.stage: SCENE, a Defile in the Neighbourhood of Thurn Castle; ALBERT, PHILIP, HERMIT, ELOISA, WOLF, and SOLDIERS.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: NOW, Comrades, mark where the declining moon, propitious to our enterprize, withdraws her fading crescent! The dark hour comes on, and warns us to the charge!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: We are all ready: our mountaineers are ambush'd within call. Where shall we storm?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Upon the western flank: the moat is fordable, and the wall weakest there: he has secured the bridge.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: I wish we had done as much before he pass'd it; but rogues are wiser in their generation than we dull downright fellows are in ours.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Ah, Philip, my whole heart is sick with dread of what has pass'd within the castle.

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: We shall soon have the castle.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Shall we have the lives within it? Shall I greet my wife? Shall I embrace my son?

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: Dismiss these terrors, and repose your hope where you have lodged your faith. Draw forth your sword! We cannot fail to conquer when those we combat are the foes of Heaven!

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: 'Tis done. Now, heroes, follow to the charge!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: A moment's patience. Where shall we bestow this aged father, and his defenceless daughter?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Wolf, you are wounded; you shall stay behind: there lives not one more worthy of that trust.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: There lives not one less likely to perform it; for though I have a reverence for old age, and a soft side towards innocence and beauty, yet if I hear the clash of swords in battle, I must, perforce, turn out and make one with them: therefore let me be foremost in the onset, and last in the retreat—there is my post.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p:
I will not hold one hero from his duty; and,
though I can no longer wield a sword, behold I have a weapon— (shows a dagger). This, and the darkness of the night, will guard us, therefore, go forth, and conquer.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: There is an arbour (Philip knows the spot) of nature's making, in the chesnut grove, beside the western tower; there we may pass the anxious minutes, and put up our prayers for your success.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Escort them to the place! We, the mean while, will martial our brave band, and for our wives, our children, and our altars, assur'd of conquest, we rush upon the foe!

div2.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment in the Castle of Thurn.

sp.p:
The monster will not let me see my child— Well! Heaven's high will be done—There was a time when my afflicted spirit was prepar'd to die with Albert! But last night in silence I commun'd with my heart, and heard a voice that seem'd to cry within me— "Hold thine hand, creature of God! thy life is not thine own, and none but he that gave can take away"— I started; left my couch; my lamp was burning; the book of life was open on my table; I read; the text was—patience—and the word of inspiration sunk into my heart with influence so persuasive, so serene, that as I read, I reasoned, and perceived when Heaven is pleased to punish,
'tis our part to suffer and submit.—Eugene, approach!
Is there not something stirring in the castle that occupies my tyrant, and reprieves me from his detested presence?

sp.speaker: EUGENE.
sp.p: I think there is—Scouts are for ever passing, that scour the country round; the walls are manned; in all the watch towers centinels are posted, and by what is going forward, I should suppose he looks to be attack'd.

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Alas! what can my helpless people do, when their brave leader's lost, and Wolf is killed, and Philip is far off?

sp.speaker: EUGENE.
sp.p: Of Philip I know nothing; but for Wolf, I must believe he lives, and that I saw him.

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Boy, you're deceived; let me not hear of hope, save what the cheering recollection gives, that all the sufferings of this transient life must have a speedy end: of this assur'd, I am prepar'd, for conscience sake, to brave all that Lazarra's fury can inflict to shake my honour, or subdue my spirit; for 'tis no question with me whom to fear—him, a contemptible and short-liv'd tyrant, that only can afflict me for awhile, or that tremendous judge whose just award is happiness or misery without end.

sp.speaker: EUGENE.
sp.p: She's gone, and knows not yet the full extent of her affliction—When she shall be told, Lord Albert fell not in the field of battle, but butchered by assassins in the dungeon of his own Belmont, what will then support her? Will sighs and tears relieve her sad despair? Oh they wou'd! I'd weep my eyes to water.

lg.l: "To sigh when sorrow loads the breast
"To weep is almost to be blest
"Sigh then, sad dame, if sighs may cheer

div2.stage: SCENE changes to the Saxon Hall.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Albert, ere this, is dead! Where is Joanna? The spark of pity that was quick within me, her insolent defiance has extinguished; my temper and my time are both exhausted; let her be summoned, and at once determine for life or death, my victim or my bride!—Do you hear me, sluggards? Which of you has charge upon the western flank?

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: I have, an' please you.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: It does not please me, sir—the wall is open. Why is the breach not stopt, as I directed?

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: We had no hands to spare from other duty.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: No, they were all employ'd upon your trenchers; you are greedy feeders all, but lazy workers. Why did you not set the prisoners upon it?

sp.speaker: OFFICER.
sp.p: The moat is fordable; we dare not trust them.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: If the moat 's fordable, where's our defence, the wall being left in breach? 'Tis well for us that Albert is not living.—Now, what news?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER.
sp.p: My lord, 'tis said that Darbony is taken.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Who says it? Who has taken him?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER.
sp.p: The fellow that was in the fight reports, Lord Albert took him prisoner.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: That is a lie as deep as to the center—Albert is dead; here's one that will confirm it: You come from Wensel?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER.
sp.p: I do, my lord, from Belmont; I am sent with humble greetings to you from my master.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Does Wensel send me Albert's head withal? If he does that, his greeting will be welcome.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER.
sp.p: Alas, my lord, I am compell'd to say that Albert has escap'd.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Infamous traitor! Wensel shall feel my vengeance! Sound to arms! Albert escap'd; and Darbony a prisoner! Call out the garrison, and man the ramparts! I'll have the prisoners put to instant death!

sp.speaker: SOLDIER.
sp.p: Arm! arm, my lord! The castle is assaulted! Your people fly! —Arm, arm, or all is lost!

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Where 's the assault?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER.
sp.p: Upon the western flank:—they have pass'd the moat!—they are within the walls!

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p:
Well, sally from the bridge, and cut them
off! Sound, sound a charge! and follow to the bridge!

div2.stage: (JOANNA rushes in, stops, listens in an attitude of horror and alarm; then exclaims—)

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Horror! Confusion! Whither shall I fly?

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Fly! Never think of flying, noble lady:— Your husband lives! he fights! he conquers!

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Lives! Does my Albert live! May I believe thee?

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: To be sure you may; Lazarra flies before him! The castle is our own! The prisoners are set free!

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: All gracious Heaven! what thanks shall I repay thee?

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: As many as you will hereafter; the fewer the better just at present; follow me, and shew yourself to your defenders; they'll fight like devils when they are led on by you. Come on! a Montfaucon is born to conquer!

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: And I will conquer, or expire with Albert!

div2.head: SCENE, a broken and picturesque Country.—On the Flank, the Bower where the HERMIT and ELOISA are concealed.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: You may come forth, my child, the storm is over.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Look, father, look; the clouds, that threaten'd us with bursts of thunder, now have roll'd away; and the sun rises red upon the mountains, a rayless ball of fire!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: So gleam'd his orb on that disastrous morn, when waking from my trance I gaz'd around with wild amaze in search of thee, and found thy bloody garment by the robbers left—Source of unnumber'd sorrows — Yet, behold, Heaven smiles upon the evening of my days—So, when this fearful conflict shall be over, the setting sun may beam serene on thee, and Philip close his triumphs in thy arms.

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: Ah, my dear father, what is that I see?—Turn, turn your eyes, and tell me who are those that issue from the castle, and now they pass the bridge, and now they fight!

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p:
By all that's terrible it is Lazarra! He sallies on the assailants— Heaven and earth! can those be Swiss that fly? Are those my countrymen
that turn their backs upon a foreign foe? Fly to your covert! Fly, my sweet child! The battle gathers towards you!

sp.speaker: ELOISA.
sp.p: I'll follow you, my father, but my heart is in the fight with Philip—Heaven protect him!

div2.stage: (The Battle.—Different Divisions are seen fighting between the Cliffs.—PHILIP appears rallying his Party.)

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: Once more, my gallant countrymen, once more charge, and you conquer! See, their battle 's broke; they reel, they stagger—Victory invites you. Philip of Belmont leads you to the charge.

div2.stage: (WENSEL, pursued by ALBERT, flies to PHILIP, who presents himself to ALBERT, covering the Fugitive.)

sp.speaker: WENSEL.
sp.p: Oh! save me, Philip, save me, or I perish!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: Stop thy avenging hand, heroic chief, nor through my filial bosom pass thy sword—Remember Belmont, and for my sake spare him —He is my father.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p:
I'll not kill thy father—Live, wretch, but never let me see thee more:—Fly to the rocks, and bid them cover thee, for the sun sickens to behold thy shame. (WENSEL retires.)
Now, Philip, forward! Lo, where brave old Wolf comes pouring down from his embattled heights to snatch the victory from us—Forward! forward!

div2.stage: (WOLF is seen engaged; his Opponents fly; he advances.)

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Well done, my cat-o'-mountains, never spare 'em; out with your claws, and bristle up your backs; the rascals dare not look upon your eyes, they glare so terribly; tear 'em and eat 'em. What between Wolf and Cat they 've had a bargain; I 've set my fangs in some of them with a vengeance.

What sculker have we here? Come out—Thou villain! thou cutpurse! who made thee a soldier, sirrah? Nature intended thee for an attorney—Come, brush your memory up, mumble a prayer, and be quick! Thou 'rt hardly worth the time 'twill take to kill thee.

sp.speaker: GUNTRAM.
sp.p: Spare me, brave Wolf! Behold, here is a ring, the signet of Lord Albert, for my safeguard— Examine it, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: WOLF
sp.p: Rascal, thou liest, thou pettifogging knave; this is not Albert's signet—thou hast stolen it.
sp.stage: (Looks for GUNTRAM, who has escaped the meanwhile)
sp.p:
Hah! gone, absconded, taken a French leave! The devil follow him! he's not worth the catching
—I'll kill the next I meet instead of him.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: I'll fly no further. Here I fix my foot, and if my soldiers will desert their leader, I've nothing but my single life to fight for, and that I'll sell as dearly as I may to him that bids for it— Albert!—

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Lazarra! I've sought you.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: You have found me.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Twice conquer'd, you have forfeited your title to the fair treatment of a loyal knight, for you have broke the truce you swore to, and, like a robber in the dead of night, forc'd my unguarded castle; conquer'd now, and all retreat cut off, you're at my mercy—Deliver up your sword, and ask your life.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: To me these terms! You little know Lazarra. I forc'd your castle—true; for in your castle there dwelt a lady, whom you dar'd to marry in violation of the laws of honour.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Honour! You ought not to pronounce the name.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: What was your honour when you fled your castle, and left Joanna in your rival's power?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Joanna's purity defies your power.

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: I suffer none to live that dare defy it. One triumph I have had, one yet remains—to vanquish thee, and perfect my revenge.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Demon incarnate! to your native hell thus I devote you. Do you feel me now?

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: As the chaf'd lion does, to rage the fiercer— (They fight. ALBERT, in parrying LAZARRA's thrust, stumbles at the root of a tree, and falls.) There, there! blest fortune!—thy star falls to earth, mine keeps its sphere.—Now thou art at my mercy.

div2.stage: (Stands over him, and points his sword at his breast.)

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: I scorn your mercy. Strike!

sp.speaker: LAZARRA.
sp.p: Expect it; but first take this truth from me— Joanna lives; you, the mean time, a solitary ghost, must wait her coming in those gloomy shades to which I now dismiss thee.

div2.stage: (As LAZARRA is in the act of killing ALBERT, JOANNA rushes in, utters a scream of horror, and strikes LAZARRA to the heart, who falls with the stroke.)

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Ah, thou murderer! Hence to those shades thyself! Behold, 'tis done—He faints, he falls, he dies—Save me, support me! Oh Philip, tell me, does my Albert live?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: He lives, he lives, he clasps thee to his heart; thou angel of his rescue.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Yes, 'twas a timely rescue o' my conscience— How came you, Sir, to fall under his sword?

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: The ground deceiv'd me as I gave back from him.

sp.speaker: WOLF.
sp.p: Aye, that fame giving back is a bad practice; but he has got his passport; he is off.

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: Look, look! he dies; convulsion shakes his frame; he gasps, he writhes in anguish, he expires!

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: Judge of all hearts, oh take him to thy mercy! He dies without a pray'r.—Horrible sight!—What Heaven inspir'd me with the strength to do, now, having done, I tremble to behold.

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p:
Take hence the body! Sound a retreat, and call in the pursuers! Now to the castle—'Tis Joanna's triumph, and we will grace it with our best display. To all my friends and brave defenders, thanks! Actions must speak my feelings;
time must shew what my full heart conceives, for language cannot. Philip, behold our venerable Hermit; and in his hand, like Truth led on by Time, thy destin'd bride approaches.

sp.speaker: HERMIT.
sp.p: Albert, if every conqueror had a cause worthy as your's, we shou'd rejoice in conquests; but in this world, for reasons only known to Heaven, bad men will triumph for a time, and be the lords and arbiters of fortune. You are both good and prosperous, and your candour in owning me the rightful Lord of Thurn, cancels your father's wrongs; but what you risqu'd your life to gain for life you shall possess. Give Philip Belmont, and I'll give him her, that wou'd convert a cottage to a palace—Take her, brave youth, she's your's!

sp.speaker: PHILIP.
sp.p: With heart and soul grateful to Heaven and you, I seal my thanks upon this beauteous hand, and greet my blessing.

sp.speaker: JOANNA.
sp.p: May years of happiness attend you both!

sp.speaker: ALBERT.
sp.p: Hence may the rash invaders of our land learn to revere the valour that defends it! Now let our gallant warriors raise their voices in celebration of this joyful day!
